image.altText: Composite of Asian Buddhist monk, an Asian woman wearing glasses, a red flag and a row of monks.

items.synopsis: For decades, an eccentric spiritual group called Holy Tantra Esoteric Buddhism has been not just accepted but celebrated in Hobart. But now, an insider desperate to reach her son is describing the group as being like a cult.

title.children: 'Don't question it': Inside the world of Tasmania's 'living Buddha'

image.altText: A house on a rural block.

items.synopsis: Police continue to investigate three suspected mushroom poisoning deaths after a family lunch last month in Leongatha in Victoria's east. Detectives have not laid any charges, but say the woman who served the meal remains a suspect. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: Three dead and another fighting for life: What we know so far about suspected mushroom poisonings in Victoria

image.altText: Australia's Hayley Raso tussles with France's Sakina Karchaoui during a football game.

items.synopsis: The Matildas need to take down France if they are to make the semifinals for the first time after Les Bleues' latest big win. Here are five things from the final round-of-16 games at the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five quick hits — Matildas learn their quarterfinal opponent, and they're running hot

title.children: 'The crowd is going to be against us': France braced for hostile Matildas atmosphere and in-form Caitlin Foord

image.altText: New Port Lincoln Curator Hayden Parker dressed in a black hoodie and black hat bending down on to touch turf pitch

image.altText: A Commonwealth Bank sign sits outside a branch of the bank, March, 2008.

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is expected to fall in morning trade, following broad losses on Wall Street as ratings agency Moody's downgraded several US banks. Reporting season continues with results from Commonwealth Bank and Suncorp. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: CBA, Suncorp profits jump, ASX to slip as Moody's downgrades US banks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Suncorp Group has reported its full-year profit surged 68.6% to $1.15 billion. It was driven by improved margins, a significant turnaround in investment returns, and strong top-line growth across the group's Insurance Australia and banking arm for the year ended June 30. Net gain from yields and investment markets was $724 million (a big improvement over the $190 million loss in the previous year). Last week, the $4.9 billion sale of Suncorp's banking arm to ANZ was blocked by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Suncorp now expects the separation (and other costs related to the deal) to increase from $500 million to between $575 million and $600 million. The company also declared a final dividend of 27 cents per share (a significant increase over last year's 17 cents per share).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Suncorp's annual profit jumps 68.6%

children.content: Suncorp Group has reported its full-year profit surged 68.6% to
$1.15 billion
It was driven by improved margins, a significant turnaround in investment returns, and strong top-line growth across the group's Insurance Australia and banking arm for the year ended June 30.
Net gain from yields and investment markets was $724 million (a big improvement over the $190 million
loss
in the previous year).
Last week, the $4.9 billion sale of Suncorp's banking arm to ANZ
was blocked
by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.
Suncorp now expects the separation (and other costs related to the deal) to increase from $500 million to between $575 million and $600 million.
The company also declared a final dividend of 27 cents per share (a significant increase over last year's 17 cents per share).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's largest bank has reported that its statutory full-year profit has jumped 5% to $10.19 billion. The Commonwealth Bank's earnings were propped up by its net interest margin (NIM) — the difference between how much the bank pays to borrow money and how much interest it charges to lend money. The bank's NIM rose to 2.07% (up 0.17 percentage points). However, its profit was somewhat weighed down by its loan impairment expenses, which rose $1.47 billion, which reflects ongoing cost of living pressures. CBA also reported that its annual cash profit (its preferred measure of earnings) lifted 6% to $10.16 billion. The company also said it will buy back an additional $1 billion worth of stock from the market, and declared a fully-franked final dividend of $2.40 per share (which is 30 cents more than a year earlier). CBA and its competitors saw their margins rebound, thanks to the Reserve Bank's aggressive rate-hiking cycle. But there are concerns about rising bad debts as the banks' mortgage units are expected to take a hit from higher borrowing costs. CBA warned that for the next financial year "competition, customer deposit switching and higher wholesale funding costs" could impact its margins, partly offset by the benefit of higher average cash rates.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Bank's annual profit rises to $10.19 billion

children.content: Australia's largest bank has reported that its statutory full-year profit has jumped 5% to
$10.19 billion.
The Commonwealth Bank's earnings were propped up by its net interest margin (NIM) — the difference between
how much the bank pays to borrow money
and
how much interest it charges to lend money
The bank's NIM rose to 2.07% (up 0.17 percentage points).
However, its profit was somewhat weighed down by its loan impairment expenses, which rose $1.47 billion, which reflects ongoing cost of living pressures.
CBA also reported that its annual
cash profit
(its preferred measure of earnings)
lifted 6% to $10.16 billion.
The company also said it will
buy back
an
additional $1 billion
worth of stock from the market, and declared a fully-franked
final dividend
of $2.40 per share (which is 30 cents more than a year earlier).
CBA and its competitors saw their margins rebound, thanks to the Reserve Bank's aggressive rate-hiking cycle.
But there are concerns about rising bad debts as the banks' mortgage units are expected to take a hit from higher borrowing costs.

CBA warned that for the next financial year "competition, customer deposit switching and higher wholesale funding costs" could impact its margins, partly offset by the benefit of higher average cash rates.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! I'll be here to guide you through today's business and economic news. The Australian share market is likely to start its day slightly lower, with ASX futures down 0.1%. It's likely to follow a weak lead from Wall Street, which was weighed down by concerns about the health of the US banking sector and broader economy. This was after Moody's cut the credit ratings of 10 small- to mid-sized US banks by one notch, and placed six banking giants (including Bank of New York Mellon, US Bancorp, State Street and Truist Financial) on review for potential downgrades. It also comes after fellow ratings agency, Fitch, downgraded the United States last week (to AA+) due to its surging debt over the next three years, and repeated down-to-the-wire debt ceiling negotiations. On top of that, Italy sent shockwaves across the European banking sector by setting a one-off 40% tax on Italian bank profits reaped from higher rates, after reprimanding lenders for failing to reward depositors. Locally, the highlight is reporting season — with Commonwealth Bank and Suncorp reporting their results today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX to slip, US banks downgraded, Italy imposes 40% windfall tax on banks

image.altText: A close up of Trump smiling in front of the stars of the American flag.

items.synopsis: Deep-diving seals satellite-tracked over two decades help scientists map the ocean floor, and a Chicago disc jockey known as DJ Casper dies aged 58. Catch up on today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Trump hearing on evidence sharing announced, and the DJ behind Cha-Cha Slide dies: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rapper Tory Lanez has been jailed for 10 years for shooting and injuring hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion in the foot in 2020. Los Angeles Superior Court Judge David Herrifor handed down the sentence to the 31-year-old who was convicted on three felonies in December. Herriford said it was “difficult to reconcile” the kind, charitable person and good father many people described Lanez as being during the sentencing hearing with the person who fired the gun at Megan. “Sometimes good people do bad things,” he said. “Actions have consequences, and there are no winners in this case.” Megan Thee Stallion that Lanez fired the gun at the back of her feet and shouted for her to dance as she walked away from an SUV in which they had been riding in July 2020, after leaving a pool party at Kylie Jenner’s Hollywood Hills home. She had to have surgery to remove bullet fragments. “Since I was viciously shot by the defendant, I have not experienced a single day of peace,” Megan said in a statement read by a prosecutor on Monday. “Slowly but surely, I’m healing and coming back, but I will never be the same.” Lanez asked the judge for mercy before his sentencing. “If I could turn back the series of events that night and change them I would," he said. “The victim was my friend, the victim is someone I still care for to this day.” “Everything I did wrong that night, I take full responsibility for.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tory Lanez sentenced to 10 years prison for shooting Megan Thee Stallion

props.alt: Tory Lanez on the left a man with a beard, tattoos and chains and a woman in a pink dress on the right

children.content: Tory Lanez and Megan Thee Stallion
(AP)
Rapper Tory Lanez has been jailed for
10 years
for shooting and injuring hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion in the foot in 2020.
Los Angeles Superior Court Judge David Herrifor handed down the sentence to the 31-year-old who was convicted on
three felonies
in December.

Herriford said it was “difficult to reconcile” the kind, charitable person and good father many people described Lanez as being during the sentencing hearing with the person who fired the gun at Megan.
“Sometimes good people do bad things,” he said.
“Actions have consequences, and there are no winners in this case.”

Megan Thee Stallion that Lanez fired the gun at the back of her feet and shouted for her to dance as she walked away from an SUV in which they had been riding in July 2020, after leaving a pool party at Kylie Jenner’s Hollywood Hills home.
She had to have surgery to remove bullet fragments.
“Since I was viciously shot by the defendant, I have not experienced a single day of peace,” Megan said in a statement read by a prosecutor on Monday.
“Slowly but surely, I’m healing and coming back, but I will never be the same.”
Lanez asked the judge for mercy before his sentencing.
“If I could turn back the series of events that night and change them I would," he said.
“The victim was my friend, the victim is someone I still care for to this day.”
“Everything I did wrong that night, I take full responsibility for.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Commonwealth Bank has posted a record profit of $10.2 billion, up 5 per cent on last financial year. The bank said profits before an increase in its provisions for bad and doubtful debts were up an even stronger 19 per cent to $15.6 billion. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Commonwealth Bank posts record $10.2 billion profit

featuredLink.title: Commonwealth Bank earnings top $10b as interest rate rises boost profit margins

children.content: The Commonwealth Bank has posted a record profit of $10.2 billion, up 5 per cent on last financial year.
The bank said profits before an increase in its provisions for bad and doubtful debts were up an even stronger 19 per cent to $15.6 billion.
You can read more here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Willie Perry Jr., a Chicago disc jockey known as DJ Casper and creator of the iconic Cha-Cha Slide dance, has died aged 58. Perry was diagnosed with cancer in 2016, and his wife confirmed his death in a statement. "Casper was a fun-loving, giving person," she says. "He was a genuine, family oriented man. He loved Chicago with all his heart. He will be greatly missed." His Cha-Cha Slide continues to be a favorite at weddings, clubs and many other events about two decades after it became popular. Participants typically dance in lines and rows, following commands to a funky beat on when and where to step, stomp, hop and slide. In a May interview, he said that the Cha-Cha Slide initially was an aerobic exercise for his nephew who worked at a fitness club. It would go on to become popular in many countries. "From there, it just took off," he said. "I have one of the biggest songs that's played at all stadiums: hockey, basketball, football, baseball, they played it at the Olympics. "It was something that everybody could do."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: DJ Casper, known for the Cha-Cha Slide, dies aged 58

children.content: (AP)
Willie Perry Jr., a Chicago disc jockey known as DJ Casper and creator of the iconic Cha-Cha Slide dance, has died aged 58.
Perry was diagnosed with cancer in 2016, and his wife confirmed his death in a statement.
"Casper was a fun-loving, giving person," she says.
"He was a genuine, family oriented man. He loved Chicago with all his heart. He will be greatly missed."
His Cha-Cha Slide continues to be a favorite at weddings, clubs and many other events about two decades after it became popular.
Participants typically dance in lines and rows, following commands to a funky beat on when and where to step, stomp, hop and slide.
In a May interview, he said that the Cha-Cha Slide initially was an aerobic exercise for his nephew who worked at a fitness club.
It would go on to become popular in many countries.
"From there, it just took off," he said.
"I have one of the biggest songs that's played at all stadiums: hockey, basketball, football, baseball, they played it at the Olympics.
"It was something that everybody could do."

title.children: John had embarked on a family trip of a lifetime. By the time he got home, criminals had stolen his identity

image.altText: Margot Robbie in a scene from Barbie, and Cillian Murphy in a scene from Oppenheimer.

items.synopsis: Movie tickets are nearly always the same price, whether the film is a flop or a sold-out blockbuster. Why? And how much more does a trip to the movies cost than 20 years ago? Peter Martin explains.

title.children: If Oppenheimer is an hour longer than Barbie, why are tickets to see them the same price?

image.altText: A close up of a crocodile on a mud flat.

title.children: Scientists are decoding saltwater crocodile 'talk'. And the reptiles have a lot to say

title.children: 'Nick's blood stains your hands': Partner of hit-and-run victim confronts driver in court

items.synopsis: A man who has type 1 diabetes is calling for more awareness after being questioned about his insulin and jelly beans while trying to enter a nightclub in Adelaide's CBD.

title.children: Man claims he was questioned at nightclub for carrying insulin for his type 1 diabetes

image.altText: Indigenous Australian holding an Aboriginal flag

title.children: What will — and won't change — after the WA government sensationally backflipped on its cultural heritage laws?

title.children: Iraq bans the term 'homosexuality', asks media to use 'sexual deviance' instead

image.altText: Three Afghan Australian men point to a sign reading 'Australian Capital Territory'. Two wear Afghan and Australian flags.

items.synopsis: For those tasked with finding human bodies, the bond between specially trained cadaver dog and handler is vital — and the physical and mental exhaustion will likely be worth it, if it can bring closure to those grieving for a loved one.

title.children: 'A privilege being able to assist': Cadaver dogs are some of Australia's most specialised canines. How are they trained?

title.children: Deep-diving seals find previously unknown underwater canyon
